An Improved Algorithm for Clustered Federated Learning

Harshvardhan, Avishek Ghosh and Arya Mazumdar
Halıcıoğlu Data Science Institute and Department of Computer Science
UC San Diego
email: {hharshvardhan,a2ghosh,arya}@@@ucsd.edu
Abstract

In this paper, we address the dichotomy between heterogeneous models and simultaneous training in Federated Learning (FL) via a clustering framework. We define a new clustering model for FL based on the (optimal) local models of the users: two users belong to the same cluster if their local models are close; otherwise they belong to different clusters. A standard algorithm for clustered FL is proposed in Ghosh et al. (2021), called IFCA, which requires suitable initialization and the knowledge of hyper-parameters like the number of clusters (which is often quite difficult to obtain in practical applications) to converge. We propose an improved algorithm, Successive Refine Federated Clustering Algorithm (SR-FCA), which removes such restrictive assumptions. SR-FCA treats each user as a singleton cluster as an initialization, and then successively refine the cluster estimation via exploiting similar users belonging to the same cluster. In any intermediate step, SR-FCA uses a robust federated learning algorithm within each cluster to exploit simultaneous training and to correct clustering errors. Furthermore, SR-FCA does not require any good initialization (warm start), both in theory and practice. We show that with proper choice of learning rate, SR-FCA incurs arbitrarily small clustering error. Additionally, we validate the performance of our algorithm on standard FL datasets in non-convex problems like neural nets, and we show the benefits of SR-FCA over baselines111The code for all experiments is available at https://github.com/harshv834/sr-fca..

1 Introduction

In modern applications like recommendation systems, natural language processing, autonomous cars, image recognition, the size of data has exploded to such a point that distributed and parallel computing has become unavoidable. Furthermore, in many applications the data is actually stored at the edge—in users’ personal devices like mobile phones and personal computers. Federated Learning, (FL) introduced in (McMahan et al., 2016; Konečnỳ et al., 2016; McMahan and Ramage, 2017) is a large scale distributed learning paradigm aimed to exploit the machine intelligence in users’ local devices. Owing to its highly decentralized nature, several statistical and computational challenges arise in FL, and in this paper, we aim to address one such challenge: heterogeneity.

The issue of heterogeneity is crucial for FL, since the data resides in users’ own devices, and naturally no two devices have identical data distribution. There has been a rich body of literature in FL to address this problem of non iid data. A line of research assumes the degree of dissimilarity across users are small, and hence focuses on learning a single global model (Zhao et al., 2018; Sahu et al., 2018a; Li et al., 2018; Sattler et al., 2019b; Mohri et al., 2019; Karimireddy et al., 2020). Note that learning a single model may not be sufficient in the situation where the degree of similarity is large or the users prefer to learn their personalized individual model. We direct the readers to two survey papers (and the references therein), Li et al. (2020); Kairouz et al. (2019) for a comprehensive list of papers on heterogeneity in FL.

As an alternative to the above, a new line of research in FL focuses on obtaining models personalized to individual users. For example Sahu et al. (2018b); Li et al. (2021) uses a regularization to obtaining individual models for users and the regularization ensures that the local models stay close to the global model. Another line of work poses the heterogeneous FL as a meta learning problem (Chen et al., 2018; Jiang et al., 2019; Fallah et al., 2020b, a). Here, the objective is to first obtain a single global model, and then each device run some local iterations (fine tune) the global model to obtain their local models. Furthermore Collins et al. (2021) exploits shared representation across users by running an alternating minimization algorithm and personalization. Note that all these personalization algorithms, including meta learning, work only when the local models of the users’ are close to one another.

On the other spectrum, when the local models of the users may not be close to one another, Sattler et al. (2019a); Mansour et al. (2020); Ghosh et al. (2021) propose a clustering framework, where the objective is to obtain individual models for each cluster. Note that Sattler et al. (2019a) uses a centralized clustering scheme, where the center has a significant amount of compute load, which is not desirable for FL. Furthermore, it uses a top-down approach using cosine similarity metric between gradient norm as optimization objective. Also, the theoretical guarantees of Sattler et al. (2019a) are limited. Further, in Duan et al. (2020), a data-driven similarity metric is used extending the cosine similarity and the framework of Sattler et al. (2019a). Moreover, in Mansour et al. (2020), the authors propose algorithms for both clustering and personalization. However, they provide guarantees only on generalization, not iterate convergence. In  Smith et al. (2017) the job of multi-task learning is framed as clustering where a regularizer in the optimization problem defines clustering objective.

Very recently, in Ghosh et al. (2021), a framework of Clustered Federated Learning is analyzed and an iterative algorithm, namely IFCA, is proposed that attains (exponential) convergence guarantees under suitable initialization. Moreover, in Ghosh et al. (2021), all the users are partitioned into a fixed and known number of clusters, and the users’ in each cluster have identical data distribution. Note that, the convergence guarantee of IFCA depends crucially on suitable initialization condition (or warm start), which is also impractical for practical applications. Furthermore, it is discussed in the same paper that the knowledge about the number of clusters is quite non-trivial to obtain in applications (see (Ghosh et al., 2021, Section 6.3)). Moreover, since the machines inside a cluster have data from a same distribution, the local models of all the machines in a cluster are identical (we formalize this in Section 3). This is a fairly strong assumption, since in FL applications, users who belong to same cluster, may have similar data. However, the data distribution may not be identical, and so, their local models are close, but not identical.

Following IFCA, a number of papers attempt to extend the federated clustering framework. For example, in Ruan and Joe-Wong (2021), a soft-clustering version of IFCA was proposed, where each data on a device can belong (probabilistic-ally) to different cluster. In Xie et al. (2020), an IFCA inspired algorithm is proposed that uses neuron matching as distance metric. Moreover, the soft clustering idea is also discussed in Li et al. (2022). To the best of our knowledge, although the above-mentioned papers extend IFCA in certain directions, the crucial shortcomings of IFCA, namely good initialization and the knowledge of the number of clusters remain unanswered.

In this paper, we propose a clustering framework for Federated Learning that overcomes the above-mentioned shortcomings. Specifically, we propose and analyze an algorithm, namely Successive Refine Federated Clustering Algorithm (SR-FCA), which iteratively estimates an refines the cluster identities of the machines. We show that, SR-FCA obtains arbitrary small clustering error. One attractive feature of SR-FCA is that it does not require the knowledge of the number of clusters apriori (instead it requires a weak condition on the minimum size of the cluster, as explained in Section 4). Moreover, SR-FCA works with arbitrary initialization, which is a major theoretical as well as practical novelty over existing literature. Furthermore, in SR-FCA we remove the requirement that all machines belonging to the same cluster possesses same local model.

To be precise, we define a novel clustering structure (see Definition 1), based on the local models on the worker machines222Throughout the paper, we use nodes, users, machines, workers synonymously to denote the compute nodes in FL.. Classically, clustering is defined in terms of distribution from which the machines sample data. However, in a federated framework, it is common to define a heterogeneous framework such as clustering in terms of other discrepancy metric; for example in Mansour et al. (2020), a metric that depends on the local loss is used.

Distance Metric: In this paper, we use a distance metric across workers’ local model as a discrepancy measure and define a clustering setup based on this. Our distance metric may in general include non-trivial metric like Wasserstein distance, ℓqsubscriptℓ𝑞\ell_{q} norm (with q≥1)q\geq 1) that captures desired practical properties like permutation invariance and sparsity for (deep) neural-net training. For our theoretical results, we focus on strongly convex and smooth loss for which ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm of iterates turns out to be the natural choice. However, for non-convex neural networks on which we run most of our experiments, we use a cross-cluster loss metric. For two clients i,j𝑖𝑗i,j, we define their cross-cluster loss metric as the average of the cross entropy loss of client i𝑖i on the model of client j𝑗j and the cross entropy loss of client j𝑗j on the model of client i𝑖i. If this metric is low, we can use the model of client i𝑖i for client j𝑗j and vice-versa, implying that the clients are similar.

With the above discrepancy metric, we put the machines in same cluster if their local models are close – otherwise they are in different clusters. We emphasize that, we do not necessarily require the local models in a cluster to be identical; a closeness condition is sufficient. Moreover, the clustering identities of the workers are unknown apriori, and SR-FCA iteratively learns them. We now list our contributions.

1.1 Our Contributions

1.1.1 Algorithmic

We introduce a new clustering framework based on local user models and propose an iterative clustering algorithm, namely SR-FCA. Our algorithm starts with simple pairwise distance based clustering, and refine those estimates (and merge in necessary) over multiple rounds. We observe that the successive refinement step exploits collaboration across users in the same cluster, and reduces the clustering error. In particular, we use the first order gradient based robust FL algorithm of Yin et al. (2018) for federation. We require a robust algorithm because we treat the wrongly clustered machines as outliers. However, we do not throw the outliers away like Yin et al. (2018); rather we reassign them to their closest cluster.

When the loss is strongly convex and smooth, and dist(.,.)\textsf{dist}(.,.) is ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm, we show that, the mis-clustering error in the first stage of SR-FCA is given by 𝒪(mdexp(−n/d)\mathcal{O}(md\exp(-n/\sqrt{d}) (Theorem 1), where m𝑚m, n𝑛n and d𝑑d denote the number of worker machines, the amount of data in each machine and the dimensionality of the problem respectively. Moreover, successive stages of SR-FCA further reduce the mis-clustering error by a factor of 𝒪​(1/m)𝒪1𝑚\mathcal{O}(1/m) (Theorem 5.1), and hence yields arbitrarily small error. In practice we require a very few refinement steps (we refine at most twice in experiments, see Section 6).

Furthermore, we compare our results with IFCA both theoretically and experimentally. We notice that the requirement on the separation of clusters is quite mild for SR-FCA. We only need the separation to be Ω~​(1n)~Ω1𝑛\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{1}{n})333Here, Ω~~Ω\tilde{\Omega} hides logarithmic dependence. On the other hand, in certain regimes, IFCA requires a separation of Ω~​(1n1/5)~Ω1superscript𝑛15\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{1}{n^{1/5}}), which is a much stronger requirement.

As a by-product of SR-FCA, we also obtain an appropriate loss minimizer for each cluster, defined in Eq. (2)—which in conjunction with our clustering model, is a reasonable good approximation for all the machines in that cluster (see Theorem 5.3). The clustering estimates are obtained by leveraging federation across similar users in a cluster. We notice that the statistical error we obtain here is 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{n}), which is weaker than IFCA (statistical error of IFCA is 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n); see (Ghosh et al., 2021, Theorem 2)). This weaker rate can be thought as the price of random initialization. For IFCA, a good initialization implies that only a very few machines are mis-clustered, which was crucially required to obtain the 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) rate. But, for SR-FCA, we do not have such guarantees to begin with, and we necessarily take a union bound on all machines, which results in a weaker statistical error.

1.1.2 Technical Novelty

A key requirement in any clustering problem is suitable initialization. However, SR-FCA removes this requirement completely, and allows the worker machines to start arbitrarily and run some number of local iterations. We show that provided the loss function is strongly convex and smooth, and the problem is well-separated, pairwise distance based clustering of these local iterates provide a reasonably good initialization, and our algorithm refines this iteratively. However, this initialization imposes further complications—for example, an original cluster can split into multiple clusters or some machines may be unassigned to any clusters. To handle all these issues, we crucially leverage (a) sharp generalization guarantees for strongly convex losses with subexponential gradients and (b) robustness property of the trimmed mean estimator (of Yin et al. (2018)).

1.1.3 Experiments

We implement SR-FCA on wide variety of datasets including synthetic, rotated or inverted MNIST, CIFAR10, FEMNIST and Shakespeare Caldas et al. (2018)). With ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} distance metric for synthetic and cross-cluster loss for the rest, we observe that the test performance of SR-FCA outperforms three baselines—(a) global (one model for all machines) and (b) local (one model per machine), (c)IFCA. Further, on synthetic and simulated datasets, SR-FCA recovers the correct clustering 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. On real datasets, SR-FCA can figure out the correct number of clusters and thus outperforms IFCA by around 4%.

2 Related Work

Data heterogeneity is a major challenge in FL, and various frameworks have been proposed in the recent past to address this. Where Zhao et al. (2018); Li et al. (2018); Mohri et al. (2019); Karimireddy et al. (2020) uses degree of dissimilarity to model the data heterogeneity, Chen et al. (2018); Fallah et al. (2020b, a) uses meta-learning to achieve the same.

Clustering is a canonical way to model heterogeneous data, and there is a significant interest in the community. Starting with the centralized cosine similarity based clustering of Sattler et al. (2019a), and multi-task based approach of Smith et al. (2017), we have the decentralized algorithm (IFCA) of Ghosh et al. (2021). Furthermore, there are several variations of IFCA; for example, in Ruan and Joe-Wong (2021); Li et al. (2022) soft-clustering versions of IFCA are proposed, in Xie et al. (2020), the authors use neuron matching as distance metric.

Apart from this, several personalized (local tuning) models for FL use ideas from clustering. For example, Fallah et al. (2020b) proposes Hypcluster algorithm, which is similar to IFCA. Moreover, Zhang et al. (2021) use personalized method which uses base clustering for knowledge transfer. Furthermore, Briggs et al. (2020) use hierarchical top-down clustering and then propagate local update steps down the hierarchy for better trained model.

3 Problem Formulation

Remark 1.

The above definition serves as a measure of heterogeneity in our system wrt 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍(.,.)\mathsf{dist}(.,.), with those inside having similar population minimizers and those in different clusters having different population minimizers.

Remark 2 (Relaxation over IFCA).

The above structure allows the population minimizers inside clusters to be close, but not necessarily equal, as opposed to  Ghosh et al. (2021)(i.e., IFCA assumes ϵ1=0subscriptitalic-ϵ10\epsilon_{1}=0).

In practice, we have access to neither Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} nor wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star}, but only the sample mean variant of the loss, the empirical risk, fi​(w)=1ni​∑j=1nif​(w,zi,j)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖𝑓𝑤subscript𝑧𝑖𝑗f_{i}(w)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}f(w,z_{i,j}), and its derivatives , for each node i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m].

ℱc​(w)=1|Gc|​∑i∈GcFi​(w),ωc∗=arg​minw∈𝒲⁡ℱc​(w),∀c∈[C].formulae-sequencesubscriptℱ𝑐𝑤1subscript𝐺𝑐subscript𝑖subscript𝐺𝑐subscript𝐹𝑖𝑤formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝜔∗𝑐subscriptargmin𝑤𝒲subscriptℱ𝑐𝑤for-all𝑐delimited-[]𝐶\displaystyle\mathcal{F}_{c}(w)=\frac{1}{\left\lvert G_{c}\right\rvert}\sum_{i\in G_{c}}F_{i}(w),\,\,\,\omega^{\ast}_{c}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w\in\mathcal{W}}\mathcal{F}_{c}(w),\,\,\forall c\in[C]. (2)

Our final goal is to find an appropriate population loss minimizer for each cluster c∈[C]𝑐delimited-[]𝐶c\in[C], i.e., ωc∗subscriptsuperscript𝜔∗𝑐\omega^{\ast}_{c}. Obtaining this involves several layers of complexity: we need to find the correct clustering 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} and recover the minimizer of each cluster. The main difficulties in this setting are: (a) the number of clusters is not known beforehand. This prevents us from using most clustering algorithms like k-means; and (b) The clustering depends on wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star} which we do not have access to. We can estimate wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star} by minimizing fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, however when n𝑛n, the minimum number of data points per node, is small, this estimate may be very far from wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star}.

In spite of the inherent complexity of our problem, we can overcome it by utilizing federation. Note that estimating wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star} is difficult if each node does not have enough data points. This apparent difficulty can be mitigated if instead we try to estimate ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star}, the population minimizer for each cluster. For each cluster, we can hope that nodes in that cluster work together to improve our estimate of ω𝒞⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝒞⋆\omega_{\mathcal{C}}^{\star}. But, this requires us to know the clustering. The circular nature of our problem implies that we need to use an alternating algorithm, which estimates ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star} in one step and then tries to cluster based on the estimates of ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star}. This forms the main idea of our clustering algorithm.

4 Algorithm-SR-FCA

In this section, we formally present out clustering algorithm, namely SR-FCA. It starts with a subroutine ONE_SHOT which outputs an initial clustering. SR-FCA then successively calls the REFINE() subroutine to improve the clustering.

In each step of REFINE(), we first estimate the cluster iterates for each cluster. Then, based on these iterates we regroup all the nodes using RECLUSTER() and then if required merge the resulting clusters, using MERGE(). We crucially require an initial clustering to start REFINE(), and ONE_SHOT provides that when REFINE() is called for the first time.

Since our goal is to end up with the correct clustering 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} and its cluster models, it is important to understand how similar any arbitrary clustering C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} (for instance the ones generated by ONE_SHOT and REFINE) is to the original clustering 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. To that end, consider a cluster c∈rg​(C′)𝑐rgsuperscript𝐶′c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}). Then, we can first define its label with respect to 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

Definition 2 (Cluster label).

We define c′∈[C]superscript𝑐′delimited-[]𝐶c^{\prime}\in[C], as the cluster label of cluster c∈rg​(C′)𝑐rgsuperscript𝐶′c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}) if the majority of nodes in c𝑐c are originally from c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime}.

This definition allows us to map each cluster c∈rg​(C′)𝑐rgsuperscript𝐶′c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}) to a cluster c𝑐c in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. Using the cluster label c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime}, we can define the impurities in cluster c𝑐c as the nodes which did not come from c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime}. Therefore, if a cluster has cluster label c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} and has very low fraction of impurities, it can serve as a good proxy for the original cluster c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

We now explain the different subroutines.

4.1 ONE_SHOT()

For our initial clustering, we create edges between nodes based on the distance between their locally trained models if 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍​(wi,wj)≤λ𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑤𝑗𝜆\mathsf{dist}(w_{i},w_{j})\leq\lambda, for a threshold λ𝜆\lambda and then obtain clusters from this graph by correlation clustering of Bansal et al. (2002). We only keep the clusters which have at least t𝑡t nodes.

If our locally trained models wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}, were close to their population minimizers wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star}, for all nodes i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m], then choosing the threshold λ∈(ϵ1,ϵ2)𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\lambda\in(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}), we obtain edges between only clients which were in the same cluster in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. However, if n𝑛n, the number of local datapoints is small, then our estimates of local models wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} might be very far from their corresponding wi⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆w_{i}^{\star} and we will not be able to recover 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

However, 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} is still a good clustering if it satisfies these requirements: (a) if every cluster in rg​(𝒞⋆)rgsuperscript𝒞⋆\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) has a good proxy (in the sense of Definition 2) in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) , and (b) each cluster in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} has at most a small fraction (<12absent12<\frac{1}{2}) of impurities in it. These requirements imply that the clusters in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} are mostly “pure” and represent all clusters in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. If the loss is structured, as shown in Theorem 1, we can obtain low mis-clustering error after ONE_SHOT.

4.2 REFINE():

Subroutine TrimmedMeanGD(): The main problem with ONE_SHOT(), namely, small n𝑛n, can be mitigated if we use federation. Since, 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} has atleast t𝑡t nodes per cluster, training a single model for each cluster will utilize t​n𝑡𝑛tn datapoints, making the estimation more accurate. However, the presence of impurities in a cluster can hamper this, motivating the use of a robust training algorithm, in this case, TrimmedMean (Yin et al., 2018).

This subroutine is similar to FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2016), but instead of taking the average of local models, we take the coordinate-wise trimmed mean. We use β<12𝛽12\beta<\frac{1}{2} to define the level of trimming and tune it in our experiments.

We end up with a trained model for each cluster as an output of this subroutine. Since these models are better estimates of their population risk minimizers, we can use them to improve 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0}.

Subroutine RECLUSTER() The purpose of this subroutine is to reduce the impurity level of each cluster in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0}. This is done by assigning each client i𝑖i to its nearest cluster c𝑐c in terms of 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍​(wc,wi)𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍subscript𝑤𝑐subscript𝑤𝑖\mathsf{dist}(w_{c},w_{i}). Since wcsubscript𝑤𝑐w_{c} are better estimates, we hope that the each impure node will go to a cluster with its actual cluster label. If we have a cluster in rg​(𝒞⋆)rgsuperscript𝒞⋆\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) which does not have a good proxy in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}), then the nodes of this cluster will always be impurities.

Subroutine MERGE(): Even after removing all impurities from each cluster, we can still end up with more than 1 cluster having the same cluster label. In 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}, these form the same cluster, thus they should be merged. If two clusters were originally from the same cluster in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}, then their learned models should be very close. Therefore, we use an approach similar to ONE_SHOT, where instead of distances between client models, we take distances between cluster models, construct edges and then merge the clusters.

Note that the complete algorithm with formal descriptions of all these subroutines can be found in Appendix A.

4.3 Discussion

SR-FCA uses a bottom-up approach to construct and refine clusters. The initialization in ONE_SHOT is obtained by distance-based thresholding on local models. These local models are improper estimates of their population minimizers due to small n𝑛n, causing 𝒞0≠𝒞⋆subscript𝒞0superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}_{0}\neq\mathcal{C}^{\star}. However, if 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} is not very bad, i.e., each cluster has <12absent12<\frac{1}{2} impurity fraction and all clusters in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} are represented, we can refine it.

REFINE() is an alternating procedure, where we first estimate cluster centers from impure clusters. Then, we RECLUSTER() to remove the impurities in each cluster and then MERGE() the clusters which should be merged according to 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. Note that as these steps use cluster estimates which are more accurate, they should have smaller error

This iterative procedure should recover one cluster for each cluster in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}, thus obtaining the number of clusters and every cluster should be pure, so that 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} is exactly recovered.

Note that the TrimmedMeanGD procedure also returns iterates, however, these may not have the best performance. Once we have recovered 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}, we can run a FL algorithm inside each cluster if we need better cluster iterates.

In the next section, we will provide theoretical justification for several of our claims and establish the probability of clustering error and convergence rates for the cluster iterates obtained by TrimmedMeanGD.

5 Theoretical Guarantees

In this section, we obtain the convergence guarantees of SR-FCA. For theoretical tractability, we restrict to the setting where the dist(.,.)(.,.) is the euclidean (ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}) norm. However, in experiments (see next section), we remove this restriction and work with other dist(.,.)(.,.) functions. Here, we show an example where ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm comes naturally as the dist(.,.)(.,.) function.

Proposition 1.

Suppose that there are m𝑚m clients, each with a local model wi⋆∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆superscriptℝ𝑑w_{i}^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and its datapoint (x,yi)∈ℝd×ℝ𝑥subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ(x,y_{i})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R} is generated according to yi=⟨wi⋆,x⟩+ϵisubscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖y_{i}=\left\langle w_{i}^{\star},x\right\rangle+\epsilon_{i}. If x∼𝒩​(0,Id)similar-to𝑥𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑x\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) and ϵi∼i.i.d𝒩​(0,σ2)superscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequence𝑖𝑖𝑑subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2\epsilon_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle i.i.d}}{{\sim}}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}), then 𝔼x[KL(p(yi|x)||p(yj|x))]=d2​σ2∥wi−wj∥2\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}_{x}[KL(p(y_{i}|x)||p(y_{j}|x))]=\frac{d}{2\sigma^{2}}\left\lVert w_{i}-w_{j}\right\rVert^{2}.

Hence, we see that minimizing a natural distance (KL divergence) between the conditional distribution y|xconditional𝑦𝑥y|x for different clients is equivalent to minimizing the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm of the underlying local models.

Our goal here is to recover both the clustering and clustering iterates. We first quantify the probability of not recovering the original clustering, i.e., Cr≠C⋆subscript𝐶𝑟superscript𝐶⋆C_{r}\neq C^{\star}. Here and subsequently, two clusters being not equal means they are not equal after relabeling (see Definition 2).

Remark 3.

Recall that in Algorithm 1, we choose λ𝜆\lambda and t𝑡t as (any) input parameter to the algorithm. However, for the guarantees of this section to hold, we require λ∈(ϵ1,ϵ2)𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\lambda\in(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}) and t≤cmin𝑡subscript𝑐t\leq c_{\min}, where cminsubscript𝑐c_{\min} is the minimum size of the cluster. We emphasize that, in practice (as shown in the experiments), we treat λ𝜆\lambda and t𝑡t as hyper-parameters and obtain them by tuning. Hence, we do not require the knowledge of ϵ1,ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2} and cminsubscript𝑐c_{\min}.

Remark 4.

Although in Algorithm 1, we use correlation clustering for finding the initial clusters, in theory, we restrict ourselves to finding cliques only. Note that if there are cliques in the graph, then correlation clustering will identify them.

We start with reviewing the standard definitions of strongly convex and smooth functions f:ℝd↦ℝ:𝑓maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}.

Definition 3.

f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex if ∀w,w′for-all𝑤superscript𝑤′\forall w,w^{\prime}, f​(w′)≥f​(w)+⟨∇f​(w),w′−w⟩+μ2​‖w′−w‖2𝑓superscript𝑤′𝑓𝑤∇𝑓𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑤𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑤′𝑤2f(w^{\prime})\geq f(w)+\langle\nabla f(w),w^{\prime}-w\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\|w^{\prime}-w\|^{2}.

Definition 4.

f𝑓f is L𝐿L-smooth if ∀w,w′for-all𝑤superscript𝑤′\forall w,w^{\prime}, ‖∇f​(w)−∇f​(w′)‖≤L​‖w−w′‖norm∇𝑓𝑤∇𝑓superscript𝑤′𝐿norm𝑤superscript𝑤′\|\nabla f(w)-\nabla f(w^{\prime})\|\leq L\|w-w^{\prime}\|.

Definition 5.

f𝑓f is Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k} Lipschitz for every coordinate k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d] if, |∂kf​(w)|≤Lksubscript𝑘𝑓𝑤subscript𝐿𝑘|\partial_{k}f(w)|\leq L_{k}, where ∂kf​(w)subscript𝑘𝑓𝑤\partial_{k}f(w) denotes the k𝑘k-th coordinate of ∇f​(w)∇𝑓𝑤\nabla f(w).

We have the following assumptions on the loss function.

Assumption 1 (Strong convexity).

The loss per sample f(w,.)f(w,.) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex with respect to w𝑤w.

Assumption 2 (Smoothness).

The loss per sample f(w,.)f(w,.) is also L𝐿L-smooth with respect to w𝑤w.

Assumption 3 (Lipschitz).

The loss per sample f(w,.)f(w,.) is Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k}-Lipschitz for every coordinate k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d]. Define L^=∑k=1dLk2^𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑘2\hat{L}=\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{d}L_{k}^{2}}.

We want to emphasize that the above assumptions are standard and have appeared in the previous literature. For example, the strong convexity and smoothness conditions are often required to obtain theoretical guarantees for clustering (see Ghosh et al. (2021); Lu and Zhou (2016), which includes IFCA and the classical k𝑘k-means which assume a quadratic objective. The coordinate-wise Lipschitz assumption is also not new and (equivalent assumptions) featured in previous works (see Yin et al. (2018, 2019). We are now ready to show the guarantees of several subroutines of SR-FCA. First, we show the probability of error after the ONE_SHOT step. Throughout this section, we require Assumptions  1, 2 and 3 to hold.

Remark 6 (Improved separation compared with IFCA).

Although we obtain an exponentially decreasing probability of error, we would like to improve this dependence. REFINE() step does this job. The theorem below shows the improvement for a single step of REFINE().

Remark 7 (Misclustering error improvement).

Note that ρ2subscript𝜌2\rho_{2} can be made arbitrarily close to 00 by a proper choice of γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} and γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2}. So, one step of REFINE() brings down the misclustering error by (almost) a factor of 1/m1𝑚1/m, where m𝑚m is the number of worker machines.

Remark 8 (Condition on B𝐵B).

Note that we require B<<2​Δ′μmuch-less-than𝐵2superscriptΔ′𝜇B<<\frac{2\Delta^{\prime}}{\mu} for the above to hold. From the definition of B𝐵B, when the intra-cluster separation ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} is small, B𝐵B is small. So, setup like IFCA, where ϵ1=0subscriptitalic-ϵ10\epsilon_{1}=0, this condition is automatically satisfied.

Theorem 5.2 (Multi-step REFINE()).

If we run R𝑅R steps of REFINE(), resampling nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} points from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and recompute wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} as in ONE_SHOT for every step of REFINE(), then the probability of error for SR-FCA with R𝑅R steps of REFINE() is

Remark 9 (Resampling).

Note that although the theoretical convergence of Multi-step REFINE() requires resampling of data points in each iteration of REFINE(), we experimentally validate (see Section 6, that this is not required at all.

Remark 10.

In experiments (Section 6), we observe that it is often sufficient to run 1−2121-2 steps of REFINE(). Since each step of REFINE() reduces the probability of misclusteing by (almost) a factor of 1/m1𝑚1/m, very few steps of REFINE() is often sufficient.

5.1 Convergence of cluster iterates:

Apart from misclustering error, we also obtain an appropriate loss minimizer for each cluster, defined in Eq. (2)—which along with our clustering model, is a reasonable good approximation for all the machines in that cluster.

Theorem 5.3 (Cluster iterates).

Under the conditions described in Theorem 5.1, after running SR-FCA for (R+1)𝑅1(R+1) steps of REFINE(), we have CR+1=C⋆superscript𝐶𝑅1superscript𝐶⋆C^{R+1}=C^{\star} and

∥ωc,T−ωc⋆∥≤(1−κ−1)T/2​D+Λ+2​B,where,​Λ=𝒪​(L^​d1−2​β​(βn+1n​cmin)​log⁡(n​m​L^​D))formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥subscript𝜔𝑐𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆superscript1superscript𝜅1𝑇2𝐷Λ2𝐵where,Λ𝒪^𝐿𝑑12𝛽𝛽𝑛1𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛𝑚^𝐿𝐷\displaystyle\left\lVert\omega_{c,T}-\omega_{c}^{\star}\right\rVert\leq(1-\kappa^{-1})^{T/2}D+\Lambda+2B,\hskip 2.84526pt\text{where,}\hskip 2.84526pt\Lambda=\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}\frac{\hat{L}d}{1-2\beta}\bigl{(}\frac{\beta}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{nc_{\min}}}\bigr{)}\sqrt{\log(nm\hat{L}D)}\bigr{)}

∀c∈rg​(C⋆)for-all𝑐rgsuperscript𝐶⋆\forall c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\star}), with probability 1−(ρ2m(1−ρ1)​p)R−mcmin​4​d​u′′(1+n​cmin​L^​D)d1superscriptsubscript𝜌2superscript𝑚1subscript𝜌1𝑝𝑅𝑚subscript𝑐4𝑑superscript𝑢′′superscript1𝑛subscript𝑐^𝐿𝐷𝑑1-\big{(}\frac{\rho_{2}}{m^{(1-\rho_{1})}}p\big{)}^{R}-\frac{m}{c_{\min}}\frac{4du^{\prime\prime}}{(1+nc_{\min}\hat{L}D)^{d}}, for some constant u′′>0superscript𝑢′′0u^{\prime\prime}>0.

The proof of the above theorem is presented in Appendix E.

Remark 11 (Convergence rate matches IFCA).

Note that the iterates converge exponentially fast to the true cluster parameter ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star}, which matches the convergence speed of IFCA.

Remark 12 (Comparison with IFCA in statistical error).

Let us now compare the error rate with that of IFCA. Note that for IFCA, ϵ1=0subscriptitalic-ϵ10\epsilon_{1}=0 and the statistical error rate of IFCA is 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) (see (Ghosh et al., 2021, Theorem 2)). Looking at Theorem 5.3, we see that under similar condition (ϵ1=0subscriptitalic-ϵ10\epsilon_{1}=0 and hence B=0𝐵0B=0), SR-FCA obtains an error rate of 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{n}), which is weaker than IFCA. This can be thought of the price of initialization. In fact for IFCA, a good initialization implies that only a very few machines will be mis-clustered, which was crucially required to obtain the 𝒪~​(1/n)~𝒪1𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) rate. But, for SR-FCA, we do not have such guarantees to begin with, and we necessarily take a union bound on all machines, which results in a weaker statistical error.

Remark 13 (Potential improvement, matching statistical error of IFCA).

We use Theorem 5.1 to bound probability of error for first R𝑅R steps and then for the (R+1)t​hsuperscript𝑅1𝑡ℎ(R+1)^{th} step we use analysis from  Yin et al. (2018) to optimize for cluster iterate convergence. Note that the cluster estimates from SR-FCA are thus good approximations of ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star}. Our iterates are obtained via TrimmedMeanGD() which assumes β𝛽\beta fraction of nodes inside each cluster are corrupted. Instead, if we run any federated optimization algorithm which can accommodate low heterogeneity, for instance FedProx Sahu et al. (2018b), inside each cluster CRsubscript𝐶𝑅C_{R}, then we can shave off the ΛΛ\Lambda term from Theorem 5.3, to obtain convergence to a neighborhood of radius 2​B2𝐵2B of ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star} for each cluster c∈C⋆𝑐superscript𝐶⋆c\in C^{\star}.

6 Experiments

6.1 Setup

We compare the empirical performance of SR-FCA against several baselines for various datasets. Throughout the experiments, we emphasize that SR-FCA does not require the knowledge of the gap ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} and ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2} or the minimum size of clusters cminsubscript𝑐c_{\min}. Our algorithm takes λ𝜆\lambda and t𝑡t as hyperparameters, where λ𝜆\lambda is set by tuning and t=2𝑡2t=2. The trimming level, β𝛽\beta in the TrimmedMeanGD subroutine, as well as all the optimizers for each problem are also obtained by tuning. Further, we recover the clusters via correlation clustering. Since correlation clustering is NP-Hard, we use a randomized approximation algorithm Bansal et al. (2002) for it. Note that in all our subroutines (RECLUSTER, MERGE, ONE_SHOT), we remove any clusters which have <tabsent𝑡<t clients. We use ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm as the distance metric for Synthetic case and for other cases, we use cross-cluster loss metric.

We compare SR-FCA against 3 baselines – local, global and IFCA, for 333 random seeds. The local baseline assumes that every client trains its own local model and the global baseline trains a single model via FedAvg McMahan and Ramage (2017) for all machine. We report the final test performance (loss or accuracy), by averaging over the clients their test performance of each client on its model, which for local is the local model, for global is the single global model and for SR-FCA and IFCA is the cluster model for the client.

We use 3 kinds of federated datasets – synthetic, simulated and real. We generate the synthetic datasets on our own, while the simulated datasets are generated from standard datasets like MNIST LeCun and Cortes (2010) and CIFAR10 Krizhevsky et al. . In these two cases, the heterogeneity and actual number of clusters and cluster identity is under our control, so for these cases we also check if SR-FCA is able to recover the cluster structure. For real federated datasets, which are obtained from leaf Caldas et al. (2018) database, we do not have this information, so we only compare final test performance.

Synthetic:

To verify our theoretical results, we first test SR-FCA for mixture of linear regression. Here, we assume two clusters, each with a different w⋆superscript𝑤⋆w^{\star} having dimension d=1000𝑑1000d=1000. Each coordinate of w⋆superscript𝑤⋆w^{\star} is generated iid from a B​e​r​n​o​u​l​l​i​(0.5)𝐵𝑒𝑟𝑛𝑜𝑢𝑙𝑙𝑖0.5Bernoulli(0.5) distribution. Each coordinate of the feature vector x𝑥x is sampled iid from 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1), and we generate the target y𝑦y as y=⟨x,w⋆⟩+ϵ𝑦𝑥superscript𝑤⋆italic-ϵy=\left\langle x,w^{\star}\right\rangle+\epsilon, where the noise ϵ​∼i​i​d​𝒩​(0,σ2)italic-ϵ𝑖𝑖𝑑similar-to𝒩0superscript𝜎2\epsilon\overset{iid}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}). We set σ=0.001𝜎0.001\sigma=0.001. We generate m=100𝑚100m=100 machines divided equally into the two clusters with n=100𝑛100n=100 datapoints per machine. We fit a linear model by minimizing the least squares loss for 280280280 iterations and report the final test metric. For SR-FCA, we use 111 refine step with ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm as the distance metric, as described in Proposition 1.

Simulated Datasets–MNIST and CIFAR 10:

We generate heterogeneous federated datasets from standard ML datasets, MNIST and CIFAR10 by splitting each dataset into m𝑚m disjoint sets of n𝑛n data points each, one per client and inject heterogeneity via pixel inversion and rotation. For MNIST, by inverting pixel value in MNIST, we create 2 clusters (referred to as inverted in Table 1) and by rotating the image by 90,180,2709018027090,180,270 degrees we get 4 clusters. For CIFAR10, we create 2 clusters by rotating the images by 180180180 degrees. Applying rotations is a common practice in continual learning setup Lopez-Paz and Ranzato (2017) and also used in past FL literature Ghosh et al. (2021). For MNIST and CIFAR10, we set (m=100,n=600)formulae-sequence𝑚100𝑛600(m=100,n=600) and (m=32,n=3125)formulae-sequence𝑚32𝑛3125(m=32,n=3125) respectively.

To emulate practical FL scenarios, we assume that only a fraction of the nodes participate in the learning procedure. For Rotated and Inverted MNIST, we assume that all the nodes participate, while for Rotated CIFAR10 50% of the nodes participate.

We use a 2-layer fully connected feed-forward Neural Net (NN) with 200200200 hidden units for MNIST, ResNet9 Page (2019) for CIFAR10 and a CNN with 2 convolution and fully connected layers for FEMNIST. For MNIST and CIFAR10, we train the models from scratch while for FEMNIST, we start from a model pre-trained by FedAvg. We train Rotated MNIST, Inverted MNIST and Rotated CIFAR10 for 250, 280 and 2400 iterations respectively with 222 refine steps for SR-FCA.

Real Dataset:

We use two real federated datasets from leaf Caldas et al. (2018) database – FEMNIST and Shakespeare.

We sample m=50𝑚50m=50 machines from each of these datasets. FEMNIST is a federated version of EMNIST Cohen et al. (2017), where each client has handwritten images from a single person. Shakespeare dataset contains dialogues from Shakespeare’s plays where every client has dialogues of a single character. The task for Shakespeare is next character prediction.

Since these are real federated datasets, we do not know the correct number of clusters for them, therefore, we run IFCA for 3,4,53453,4,5 clusters respectively and report the average test accuracy.

For FEMNIST, we use a CNN with 2 convolution and fully connected layers and for Shakespeare, we use a 2-layer Stacked LSTM with an embedding layer. We run FEMNIST and Shakespeare for 100010001000 and 240024002400 iterations respectively and set number of refine steps to be 222 for SR-FCA.

6.2 Results

From Table 1 we can see that across all different datasets, SR-FCA outperforms all baselines.

Comparison with Local and Global Baselines:

Note that the local model has access to very little data, while the global model cannot handle the heterogeneity in different clusters. Therefore, both IFCA and SR-FCA outperform these baselines as they identify correct clusters with low heterogeneity inside each cluster. Further, the difference in test performance between these baselines and SR-FCA increases if we reduce the number of datapoints per client or increase the heterogeneity between clients.

Recovering the correct clustering 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}:

Apart from the real datasets, the correct clustering is known to us beforehand. In these cases, SR-FCA recovers the correct clustering, if the distance metric and the threshold λ𝜆\lambda is tuned properly. The task of tuning λ𝜆\lambda is especially simplified for simulated datasets, as the heterogeneity for clients inside the cluster (i.e., ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1}) is 0. In this setup, we observe that ONE_SHOT is near sufficient to recover 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. For real datasets, this observation is not true and we require multiple REFINE steps.

Comparison with IFCA:

On simulated and synthetic datasets, the number of clusters is already known, thus the performance of SR-FCA is similar to that of IFCA. However, for real datasets this is unknown, and SR-FCA clearly outperforms IFCA, especially for Shakespeare.

We first emphasize that the accuracy we report here are somewhat different compared to Ghosh et al. (2021). The main reason is that for fair comparison, we average the accuracy over multiple random seed, while in Ghosh et al. (2021), the maximum accuracy over seeds is reported.

As we run IFCA without initialization, we find that if clusters are empty early in training, then they remain empty throughout training. For Shakespeare, with K=5𝐾5K=5 clusters, we ended up with 2 empty clusters. SR-FCA does not suffer from these issues due to the appropriate initialization from ONE_SHOT.

Additionally, note that the number of clusters in a small sample of a real dataset is not fixed, therefore averaged over different seeds, IFCA performs poorly for each value of K𝐾K. SR-FCA on the other hand, can compute both the clustering and cluster iterates without the knowledge of K𝐾K, thereby beating IFCA.

An interesting example of the issues with IFCA is the Shakespeare dataset. SR-FCA recovers exactly 111 cluster in this case, therefore it’s accuracy is close to the global baseline. IFCA, on the other hand, tries to fit K=3,4,5𝐾345K=3,4,5 clusters to this dataset and therefore performs poorly.

Key Takeaways from experiments:

We summarize the key takeaways from our experiments – (1) SR-FCA outperforms all baselines across all datasets; (2) SR-FCA recovers the true clustering C⋆superscript𝐶⋆C^{\star} for synthetic and simulated datasets; (3)SR-FCA outperforms IFCA especially for real datasets.

Appendix

Appendix A Algorithm Description

We provide complete descriptions for the subroutines in REFINE namely – TrimmedMeanGD, RECLUSTER and MERGE.

Subroutine TrimmedMeanGD(): The full algorithm for TrimmendMeanGD is provided in Algorithm 2.

Definition 6 (TrMeanβsubscriptTrMean𝛽\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta}).

For β∈[0,12)𝛽012\beta\in[0,\frac{1}{2}), and a set of vectors xj∈ℝd,j∈[J]formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥𝑗superscriptℝ𝑑𝑗delimited-[]𝐽x^{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},j\in[J], their trimmed mean g=TrMeanβ​({x1,x2,…,xJ})𝑔subscriptTrMean𝛽superscript𝑥1superscript𝑥2…superscript𝑥𝐽g=\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta}(\{x^{1},x^{2},\ldots,x^{J}\}) is a vector g∈ℝd𝑔superscriptℝ𝑑g\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with each coordinate gk=1(1−2​β)​J​∑x∈Ukxsubscript𝑔𝑘112𝛽𝐽subscript𝑥subscript𝑈𝑘𝑥g_{k}=\frac{1}{(1-2\beta)J}\sum_{x\in U_{k}}x, for each k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d], where Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k} is a subset of {xk1,xk2,…,xkJ}superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝐽\{x_{k}^{1},x_{k}^{2},\ldots,x_{k}^{J}\} obtained by removing the smallest and largest β𝛽\beta fraction of its elements.

Note that TrMeanβsubscriptTrMean𝛽\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta} has been used to handle Byzantine nodes achieving optimal statistical rates Yin et al. (2018). TrMeanβsubscriptTrMean𝛽\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta} can handle atmost <βabsent𝛽<\beta fraction of the nodes being byzantine, therefore, we need ONE_SHOT to return clusters where each has <βabsent𝛽<\beta fraction of impurities for our theoretical results.

Note that in our experiments, we use >1absent1>1 local steps and take TrMeanβsubscriptTrMean𝛽\texttt{TrMean}_{\beta} when averaging local models.

Subroutine RECLUSTER(): The full algorithm is provided in Algorithm 3. Each client is sent to the cluster which is closest to it, in terms of 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍​(wi,ωc)𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝜔𝑐\mathsf{dist}(w_{i},\omega_{c}).

Subroutine MERGE(): The full algorithm is provided in Algorithm 4. Similar to ONE_SHOT, we create a graph G𝐺G but instead with vertex set being the clusters in 𝒞r′superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r}^{\prime}. Then, we add edges between clusters based on the threshold and find all the clusters in the resultant graph G𝐺G by correlation clustering. Then, each of these clusters in G𝐺G correspond to a set of clusters in 𝒞r′superscriptsubscript𝒞𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r}^{\prime}, so we merge them into a single cluster to obtain the final clustering 𝒞r+1subscript𝒞𝑟1\mathcal{C}_{r+1}.

Appendix B Proof of Proposition 1

According to the proposition, for two users i𝑖i and j𝑗j, the data is generated by first sampling each coordinate of x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1) iid and then computing y𝑦y as –

yi=⟨x,wi⋆⟩+ϵisubscript𝑦𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\displaystyle y_{i}=\left\langle x,w_{i}^{\star}\right\rangle+\epsilon_{i}

where ϵi​∼i​i​d​𝒩​(0,σ2)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑖𝑖𝑑similar-to𝒩0superscript𝜎2\epsilon_{i}\overset{iid}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}). Then, the distribution of yi|xconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑥y_{i}|x is 𝒩​(⟨x,wi⋆⟩,σ2)𝒩𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(\left\langle x,w_{i}^{\star}\right\rangle,\sigma^{2}). Therefore, the K​L𝐾𝐿KL divergence between yi|xconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑥y_{i}|x and yj|xconditionalsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑥y_{j}|x is given by

KL(p(yi|x)||p(yj|x))=⟨wi⋆−wj⋆,x⟩22​σ2\displaystyle KL(p(y_{i}|x)||p(y_{j}|x))=\frac{\left\langle w_{i}^{\star}-w_{j}^{\star},x\right\rangle^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}

Therefore, if we take expectation wrt x𝑥x, we have

𝔼x[KL(p(yi|x)||p(yj|x))]=d​∥wi⋆−wj⋆∥22​σ2\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}_{x}[KL(p(y_{i}|x)||p(y_{j}|x))]=\frac{d\left\lVert w_{i}^{\star}-w_{j}^{\star}\right\rVert^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 1

Note that throughout the proof, we treat wi,Tsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑇w_{i,T} as the output of it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} node after training for T𝑇T, instead of wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and wc,Tsubscript𝑤𝑐𝑇w_{c,T} as the output of the ct​hsuperscript𝑐𝑡ℎc^{th} cluster after TrimmedMeanGD for T𝑇T iterations.

In ONE_SHOT(), 𝒞0=𝒞⋆subscript𝒞0superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}_{0}=\mathcal{C}^{\star}, if all the edges formed in the graph are correct. This means that if i,j𝑖𝑗i,j are in the same cluster in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}, then ∥wi,T−wj,T∥≤λdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤𝑖𝑇subscript𝑤𝑗𝑇𝜆\left\lVert w_{i,T}-w_{j,T}\right\rVert\leq\lambda and if i,j𝑖𝑗i,j are in different clusters, ∥wi,T−wj,T∥>λdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤𝑖𝑇subscript𝑤𝑗𝑇𝜆\left\lVert w_{i,T}-w_{j,T}\right\rVert>\lambda.

Note that,

wi,T−wj,T=(wi⋆−wj⋆)+(wi,T−wi⋆)−(wj,T−wj⋆)subscript𝑤𝑖𝑇subscript𝑤𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗⋆subscript𝑤𝑖𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆subscript𝑤𝑗𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗⋆\displaystyle w_{i,T}-w_{j,T}=(w_{i}^{\star}-w_{j}^{\star})+(w_{i,T}-w_{i}^{\star})-(w_{j,T}-w_{j}^{\star})

Now, if we apply triangle inequality, we obtain

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 5.1

D.1 Preliminaries

First, we define certain random variables and their respective probabilities which we will use throughout this proof. Since the edge based analysis and corresponding clique identification involves a lot of dependent events, we try to decompose the absence/presence of edge into a combination of independent events.

Define,

Xi​j={1If the edge (i,j) in 𝒞0 is incorrect in 𝒞⋆0Otherwisesubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗cases1If the edge (i,j) in 𝒞0 is incorrect in 𝒞⋆0Otherwise\displaystyle X_{ij}=\begin{cases}1&\text{If the edge $(i,j)$ in $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ is incorrect in $\mathcal{C}^{\star}$}\\ 0&\text{Otherwise}\\ \end{cases} (11)

An edge (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} is incorrect in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} if either it is present in 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} and absent in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} or vice versa. We analyze the probability of this event for the case when 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} contains the edge (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). The case when 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} doesn’t contain edge (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) and it is present in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} has exaclty same probability. When ∥wi⋆−wj⋆∥≤ϵ1delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗⋆subscriptitalic-ϵ1\left\lVert w_{i}^{\star}-w_{j}^{\star}\right\rVert\leq\epsilon_{1}, then edge is present is 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star}. If it is absent in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0}, then

Pr⁡[Xi​j=1]≤Prsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗1absent\displaystyle\Pr[X_{ij}=1]\leq Pr⁡[Ξi,j≥Δλ]PrsubscriptΞ𝑖𝑗subscriptΔ𝜆\displaystyle\Pr[\Xi_{i,j}\geq\Delta_{\lambda}]
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr⁡[Λi+Λj≥2​Δ]PrsubscriptΛ𝑖subscriptΛ𝑗2Δ\displaystyle\Pr[\Lambda_{i}+\Lambda_{j}\geq 2\Delta]

The analysis is similar to the proof of ONE_SHOT() in Appendix C.

Note that the random variables {Xi​j}subscript𝑋𝑖𝑗\{X_{ij}\} are not independent. We now define independent random variables Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} such that

Xi={1If Λi≥Δ0Otherwisesubscript𝑋𝑖cases1If Λi≥Δ0Otherwise\displaystyle X_{i}=\begin{cases}1&\text{If $\Lambda_{i}\geq\Delta$}\\ 0&\text{Otherwise}\end{cases} (12)

Thus, we can see that Xi​j≤Xi+Xjsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗X_{ij}\leq X_{i}+X_{j}. Additionally,

Pr⁡[Xi=1]≤Pr⁡[Λi≥Δ]≤pmPrsubscript𝑋𝑖1PrsubscriptΛ𝑖Δ𝑝𝑚\displaystyle\Pr[X_{i}=1]\leq\Pr[\Lambda_{i}\geq\Delta]\leq\frac{p}{m} (13)

This follows from analysis of ONE_SHOT() in Appendix C.

We can further generalize this notion to the random variables defined as Yi,γsubscript𝑌𝑖𝛾Y_{i,\gamma}.

Yi,γ={1If Λi≥γ​Δ,γ∈(0,2)0Otherwisesubscript𝑌𝑖𝛾cases1If Λi≥γΔ,γ∈(0,2)0Otherwise\displaystyle Y_{i,\gamma}=\begin{cases}1&\text{If $\Lambda_{i}\geq\gamma\Delta,\gamma\in(0,2)$}\\ 0&\text{Otherwise}\end{cases} (14)

Then,

Pr⁡[Yi,γ=1]≤Prsubscript𝑌𝑖𝛾1absent\displaystyle\Pr[Y_{i,\gamma}=1]\leq Pr⁡[Λi≥γ​Δ]≤d​exp⁡(−n​b2​γ​ΔL^​d)=(pm)γPrsubscriptΛ𝑖𝛾Δ𝑑𝑛subscript𝑏2𝛾Δ^𝐿𝑑superscript𝑝𝑚𝛾\displaystyle\Pr[\Lambda_{i}\geq\gamma\Delta]\leq d\,\exp(-nb_{2}\frac{\gamma\Delta}{\hat{L}\sqrt{d}})=(\frac{p}{m})^{\gamma}

Note that the set of random variables {Yi,γ}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑌𝑖𝛾𝑖1𝑚\{Y_{i,\gamma}\}_{i=1}^{m} are mutually independent random variables.

If Gc={i:i∈[m],𝒞⋆​(i)=c′}subscript𝐺𝑐conditional-set𝑖formulae-sequence𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscript𝒞⋆𝑖superscript𝑐′G_{c}=\{i:i\in[m],\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=c^{\prime}\}, which is the set of nodes in c𝑐c which were from c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} in the original clustering, then we can define ωc⋆superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑐⋆\omega_{c}^{\star} and Fc​(w)subscript𝐹𝑐𝑤F_{c}(w) as

D.2 Analysis of REFINE()

Our goal is to compute total probability of error for REFINE() to fail. If we define this error as 𝒞1≠𝒞⋆subscript𝒞1superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}_{1}\neq\mathcal{C}^{\star}, then we can define the main sources of error for this event.

  1. 1.

    ∃c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) such that no cluster in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} has cluster label c𝑐c : If the a cluster c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) is absent in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0}, then subsequent steps of REFINE() will never be able to recover it, as they only involve node reclustering and merging existing clusters. The lemma presented below gives an upper bound on the probability of this event.

    Lemma 4.

    Under the conditions of Theorem 1 and if t=Θ​(cmin)𝑡Θsubscript𝑐t=\Theta(c_{\min}), then there exists constant a1>0subscript𝑎10a_{1}>0 such that

    Pr⁡[∃c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)​ such that no cluster in 𝒞0 has cluster label c]≤mcmin​exp⁡(−a1​cmin)Pr𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆ such that no cluster in 𝒞0 has cluster label c𝑚subscript𝑐subscript𝑎1subscript𝑐\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star})\text{ such that no cluster in $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ has cluster label $c$}]\leq\frac{m}{c_{\min}}\exp(-a_{1}c_{\min})

    The proof of this Lemma is presented in Appendix D.3

  2. 2.

    Each cluster c∈rg​(C)0𝑐rgsubscript𝐶0c\in\mathrm{rg}(C)_{0} should have <αabsent𝛼<\alpha fraction of impurities for some 12>β>α12𝛽𝛼\frac{1}{2}>\beta>\alpha: If some cluster has more than α𝛼\alpha-fraction of impure nodes, then we cannot expect convergence guarantees for TrimmedMeanGDβ.

    The below lemma bounds the probability of this error as

    Lemma 5.

    Pr⁡[∃c∈rg​(𝒞0)​ which has >α fraction of impurities ]≤mt​exp⁡(−a2​m)+(1−α)​m​(pm)γ1Pr𝑐rgsubscript𝒞0 which has >α fraction of impurities 𝑚𝑡subscript𝑎2𝑚1𝛼𝑚superscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝛾1\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})\text{ which has $>\alpha$ fraction of impurities }]\leq\frac{m}{t}\exp(-a_{2}m)+(1-\alpha)m(\frac{p}{m})^{\gamma_{1}}

    The proof of this Lemma is presented in Appendix D.4.

  3. 3.

    MERGE() error: We define this as the error for the MERGE() to fail. Even though MERGE() operates after RECLUSTER(), RECLUSTER() does not change the cluster iterates. The goal of MERGE() is to ensure that all clusters in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} with the same cluster labels are merged. Therefore, we define MERGE() error as the event when either two clusters with same cluster label are not merged or two clusters with different cluster labels are merged. The below lemma bounds this probability.

    Lemma 6.

    If min⁡{n2/3​Δ4/3D2/3​L^2/3,n2​Δ′⁣2L^2​log⁡(cmin)}≥u1​dsuperscript𝑛23superscriptΔ43superscript𝐷23superscript^𝐿23superscript𝑛2superscriptΔ′2superscript^𝐿2subscript𝑐subscript𝑢1𝑑\min\{\frac{n^{2/3}\Delta^{4/3}}{D^{2/3}\hat{L}^{2/3}},\frac{n^{2}\Delta^{\prime 2}}{\hat{L}^{2}\log(c_{\min})}\}\geq u_{1}d for some constants u1>0subscript𝑢10u_{1}>0, then for some constant a3′>0superscriptsubscript𝑎3′0a_{3}^{\prime}>0, where Δ′=Δ−μ​B2>0superscriptΔ′Δ𝜇𝐵20\Delta^{\prime}=\Delta-\frac{\mu B}{2}>0, where B=2​L^​ϵ1μ𝐵2^𝐿subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝜇B=\sqrt{\frac{2\hat{L}\epsilon_{1}}{\mu}}, we have

    Pr⁡[MERGE() Error]≤4​d​mt​exp⁡(−a3′​n​Δ′2​L^)PrMERGE() Error4𝑑𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑎3′𝑛superscriptΔ′2^𝐿\displaystyle\Pr[\texttt{MERGE()}\text{ Error}]\leq\frac{4dm}{t}\exp(-a_{3}^{\prime}n\frac{\Delta^{\prime}}{2\hat{L}})

    The proof of this Lemma is presented in Appendix D.5.

  4. 4.

    RECLUSTER() error: This event is defined as a node going to the wrong cluster after both MERGE() and REFINE() operations. After MERGE(), each cluster in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} corresponds to a single cluster in 𝒞1subscript𝒞1\mathcal{C}_{1}. D.3 Proof of Lemma 4

Pr⁡[∃c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)​ such that no cluster in 𝒞0 has cluster label c]≤∑c∈𝒞⋆Pr⁡[No cluster in ​𝒞0​ has cluster label c]Pr𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆ such that no cluster in 𝒞0 has cluster label csubscript𝑐superscript𝒞⋆PrNo cluster in subscript𝒞0 has cluster label c\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star})\text{ such that no cluster in $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ has cluster label $c$}]\leq\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}^{\star}}\Pr[\text{No cluster in }\mathcal{C}_{0}\text{ has cluster label $c$}] (20)

Here, we use union bound over the clusters for the second inequality. Now, we analyze the probability that no cluster in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) has cluster label c𝑐c for some c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}). Consider a cluster in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}). This cluster has cluster label c𝑐c if a majority of its nodes are from cluster c∈rg​(𝒞⋆)𝑐rgsuperscript𝒞⋆c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}). Since the size of each cluster in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) is atleast t𝑡t and there are C𝐶C clusters in rg​(𝒞⋆)rgsuperscript𝒞⋆\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}), if all clusters in rg​(𝒞0)rgsubscript𝒞0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) have ≤tCabsent𝑡𝐶\leq\frac{t}{C} nodes from cluster c𝑐c, then no cluster will have cluster label c𝑐c.

Assume that the clique formed by nodes from cluster c𝑐c has r𝑟r nodes. Then, every node i𝑖i in cluster c𝑐c, must have Sc−rsubscript𝑆𝑐𝑟S_{c}-r edges absent, which correspond to the edges between a node of the clique and those outside it. Thus, we obtain,

Pr⁡[No cluster in ​𝒞0​ has cluster label c]≤PrNo cluster in subscript𝒞0 has cluster label cabsent\displaystyle\Pr[\text{No cluster in }\mathcal{C}_{0}\text{ has cluster label $c$}]\leq Pr⁡[∩𝒞⋆​(i)=c​{∑j≠i,𝒞⋆​(i)=cXi​j>Sc−tC}]Prsuperscript𝒞⋆𝑖𝑐subscriptformulae-sequence𝑗𝑖superscript𝒞⋆𝑖𝑐subscript𝑋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶\displaystyle\Pr[\underset{\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=c}{\cap}\{\sum_{j\neq i,\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=c}X_{ij}>S_{c}-\frac{t}{C}\}]
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr⁡[∑∑𝒞⋆​(i)=𝒞⋆​(j)=c​Xi​j>Sc​(Sc−tC)]Prsuperscript𝒞⋆𝑖superscript𝒞⋆𝑗𝑐subscript𝑋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑐subscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶\displaystyle\Pr[\underset{\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=\mathcal{C}^{\star}(j)=c}{\sum\sum}X_{ij}>S_{c}(S_{c}-\frac{t}{C})]
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr⁡[∑∑𝒞⋆​(i)=𝒞⋆​(j)=c​(Xi+Xj)>Sc​(Sc−tC)]Prsuperscript𝒞⋆𝑖superscript𝒞⋆𝑗𝑐subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑆𝑐subscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶\displaystyle\Pr[\underset{\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=\mathcal{C}^{\star}(j)=c}{\sum\sum}(X_{i}+X_{j})>S_{c}(S_{c}-\frac{t}{C})]
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr[1Sc∑𝒞⋆​(i)=cXi>1−tC​Sc)]\displaystyle\Pr[\frac{1}{S_{c}}\underset{\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=c}{\sum}X_{i}>1-\frac{t}{CS_{c}})]
≤\displaystyle\leq exp⁡(−(1−tC​Sc−pm)2​Sc)superscript1𝑡𝐶subscript𝑆𝑐𝑝𝑚2subscript𝑆𝑐\displaystyle\exp(-\biggl{(}1-\frac{t}{CS_{c}}-\frac{p}{m}\biggr{)}^{2}S_{c})
≤\displaystyle\leq exp⁡(−a1​cmin)subscript𝑎1subscript𝑐\displaystyle\exp(-a_{1}c_{\min})

In the first step, we require each node i𝑖i to have Sc−tCsubscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶S_{c}-\frac{t}{C} wrong edges. For the second inequality, we remove the intersection and thus, the total number of incorrect edges has to be Sc​(Sc−tC)subscript𝑆𝑐subscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶S_{c}(S_{c}-\frac{t}{C}), since each node has Sc−tCsubscript𝑆𝑐𝑡𝐶S_{c}-\frac{t}{C} incorrect edges. For the third inequality, we use Xi​j≤Xi+Xjsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑗subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗X_{ij}\leq X_{i}+X_{j} and collect the terms of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} for the fourth inequality. In the fifth inequality, we obtain a condition on the sum of independent Bernoulli random variables each with mean pm𝑝𝑚\frac{p}{m}. Therefore, we can apply Chernoff bound for their sum to obtain the fifth inequality.

A necessary condition for us is 1−tC​Sc−pm>01𝑡𝐶subscript𝑆𝑐𝑝𝑚01-\frac{t}{CS_{c}}-\frac{p}{m}>0 which translates to t<C​Sc​(1−pm)𝑡𝐶subscript𝑆𝑐1𝑝𝑚t<CS_{c}(1-\frac{p}{m}). If we select t≤cm​i​n−1𝑡subscript𝑐𝑚𝑖𝑛1t\leq c_{min}-1, this inequality is always satisfied. Note that we want the term (1−tC​Sc−pm)2>a1superscript1𝑡𝐶subscript𝑆𝑐𝑝𝑚2subscript𝑎1\biggl{(}1-\frac{t}{CS_{c}}-\frac{p}{m}\biggr{)}^{2}>a_{1}, for some positive constant a1subscript𝑎1a_{1}. If we choose t=Θ​(m)𝑡Θ𝑚t=\Theta(m), which is possible if t=Θ​(cmin)𝑡Θsubscript𝑐t=\Theta(c_{\min}) as we assume cmin=Θ​(m)subscript𝑐Θ𝑚c_{\min}=\Theta(m), then this is satisfied. We use the lower bound a1subscript𝑎1a_{1} and Sc≥cminsubscript𝑆𝑐subscript𝑐S_{c}\geq c_{\min} to obtain the final inequality. Plugging this in Eq (20), we obtain our result.

D.4 Proof of Lemma 5

Pr[∃c∈rg(𝒞0) which has ≥α fraction of impurities]≤∑c∈rg​(𝒞0)Pr[cluster c has ≥α fraction of wrong nodes]\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})\text{ which has $\geq\alpha$ fraction of impurities}]\quad\leq\sum_{c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})}\Pr[\text{cluster $c$ has $\geq\alpha$ fraction of wrong nodes}] (21)

We use a simple union bound on clusters in 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} for the above inequality. Let the set of nodes in the cluster c𝑐c which are from same cluster of 𝒞⋆superscript𝒞⋆\mathcal{C}^{\star} as the cluster label of c𝑐c, i.e., which are not impurities, be Rcsubscript𝑅𝑐R_{c}. Then let Qc=|Rc|subscript𝑄𝑐subscript𝑅𝑐Q_{c}=\left\lvert R_{c}\right\rvert. Let Qc′subscriptsuperscript𝑄′𝑐Q^{\prime}_{c} denote the number of impurities in cluster c𝑐c.

Pr⁡[Qc′≥α​t]Prsubscriptsuperscript𝑄′𝑐𝛼𝑡\displaystyle\Pr[Q^{\prime}_{c}\geq\alpha t]

Now, we analyze the probability of a single node to be incorrect. A node is an impurity in cluster c𝑐c if it has an edge to each of nodes in Rcsubscript𝑅𝑐R_{c}.

Pr⁡[Node i is an impurity in cluster c]≤PrNode i is an impurity in cluster cabsent\displaystyle\Pr[\text{Node $i$ is an impurity in cluster c}]\leq Pr⁡[minj∈Rc⁡∥wi,T−wj,T∥≤λ]Prsubscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscript𝑤𝑖𝑇subscript𝑤𝑗𝑇𝜆\displaystyle\Pr[\min_{j\in R_{c}}\left\lVert w_{i,T}-w_{j,T}\right\rVert\leq\lambda] (22)
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr⁡[minj∈Rc⁡(∥wi⋆−wj⋆∥−Ξi,j)≤λ]Prsubscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑗⋆subscriptΞ𝑖𝑗𝜆\displaystyle\Pr[\min_{j\in R_{c}}(\left\lVert w_{i}^{\star}-w_{j}^{\star}\right\rVert-\Xi_{i,j})\leq\lambda] (23)
≤\displaystyle\leq Pr⁡[Λi+maxj∈Rc⁡Λj≥2​Δ]PrsubscriptΛ𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscriptΛ𝑗2Δ\displaystyle\Pr[\Lambda_{i}+\max_{j\in R_{c}}\Lambda_{j}\geq 2\Delta] (24)

Now, if maxj∈Rc⁡Λj≤γ1​Δsubscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscriptΛ𝑗subscript𝛾1Δ\max_{j\in R_{c}}\Lambda_{j}\leq\gamma_{1}\Delta, for γ1∈(1,2)subscript𝛾112\gamma_{1}\in(1,2), then we need Λi≥(2−γ1)​ΔsubscriptΛ𝑖2subscript𝛾1Δ\Lambda_{i}\geq(2-\gamma_{1})\Delta for error.

Using the definition of random variables in Appendix D.1

Pr⁡[Qc′≥α​t]≤Prsubscriptsuperscript𝑄′𝑐𝛼𝑡absent\displaystyle\Pr[Q^{\prime}_{c}\geq\alpha t]\leq Pr⁡[Qc′≥α​t|maxj∈Rc⁡Λj≤γ1​Δ]+Pr⁡[maxj∈Rc⁡Λj≥γ1​Δ]Prsubscriptsuperscript𝑄′𝑐conditional𝛼𝑡subscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscriptΛ𝑗subscript𝛾1ΔPrsubscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscriptΛ𝑗subscript𝛾1Δ\displaystyle\Pr[Q^{\prime}_{c}\geq\alpha t|\max_{j\in R_{c}}\Lambda_{j}\leq\gamma_{1}\Delta]+\Pr[\max_{j\in R_{c}}\Lambda_{j}\geq\gamma_{1}\Delta]

Pr⁡[maxj∈Rc⁡Λj≥γ1​Δ]≤Qc​Pr⁡[Yj,γ1=1]≤Qc​(pm)γ1Prsubscript𝑗subscript𝑅𝑐subscriptΛ𝑗subscript𝛾1Δsubscript𝑄𝑐Prsubscript𝑌𝑗subscript𝛾11subscript𝑄𝑐superscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝛾1\displaystyle\Pr[\max_{j\in R_{c}}\Lambda_{j}\geq\gamma_{1}\Delta]\leq Q_{c}\Pr[Y_{j,\gamma_{1}}=1]\leq Q_{c}(\frac{p}{m})^{\gamma_{1}}

Here, we use union bound over all elements in Rcsubscript𝑅𝑐R_{c} for the first inequality and the second inequality is plugging in the value of Pr⁡[Yj,γ1=1]Prsubscript𝑌𝑗subscript𝛾11\Pr[Y_{j,\gamma_{1}}=1], which we have already computed.

Now, we need to provide a bound on Qcsubscript𝑄𝑐Q_{c}. Note that if Qcsubscript𝑄𝑐Q_{c} denotes the correct number of nodes, which corresponds to the majority of nodes, then Qc≤(1−α)​Scsubscript𝑄𝑐1𝛼subscript𝑆𝑐Q_{c}\leq(1-\alpha)S_{c}, where Scsubscript𝑆𝑐S_{c} is the size of the cluster c𝑐c.

For the first term, we can use Chernoff bound as Yi,2−γ1subscript𝑌𝑖2subscript𝛾1Y_{i,2-\gamma_{1}} are independent random variables with expectation pm𝑝𝑚\frac{p}{m}

Pr⁡[1m​∑i=1mYi,2−γ1≥α​tm]≤exp⁡(−(α​tm−𝔼⁡[Yi,2−γ1])2​m)≤exp⁡(−a2​m)Pr1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑌𝑖2subscript𝛾1𝛼𝑡𝑚superscript𝛼𝑡𝑚𝔼subscript𝑌𝑖2subscript𝛾12𝑚subscript𝑎2𝑚\displaystyle\Pr[\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}Y_{i,2-\gamma_{1}}\geq\alpha\frac{t}{m}]\leq\exp(-(\alpha\frac{t}{m}-\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}[Y_{i,2-\gamma_{1}}])^{2}m)\leq\exp(-a_{2}m)

We need α​tm≥𝔼⁡[Yi,2−γ1]𝛼𝑡𝑚𝔼subscript𝑌𝑖2subscript𝛾1\alpha\frac{t}{m}\geq\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}[Y_{i,2-\gamma_{1}}],which implies α​t≥1𝛼𝑡1\alpha t\geq 1, since Yi,2−γ1subscript𝑌𝑖2subscript𝛾1Y_{i,2-\gamma_{1}} is a bernoulli random variable. Further, we require α​t=Θ​(m)𝛼𝑡Θ𝑚\alpha t=\Theta(m), so that we can bound the probability using a constant a2≥0subscript𝑎20a_{2}\geq 0. If we choose γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} as a constant independent of m𝑚m, then we are done.

Now, plugging all these inequalities into Eq (21), we get

≤rg​(𝒞0)​exp⁡(−a2​m)+∑c∈rg​(𝒞0)(1−α)​Sc​(pm)γ1absentrgsubscript𝒞0subscript𝑎2𝑚subscript𝑐rgsubscript𝒞01𝛼subscript𝑆𝑐superscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝛾1\displaystyle\quad\leq\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})\exp(-a_{2}m)+\sum_{c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})}(1-\alpha)S_{c}(\frac{p}{m})^{\gamma_{1}}

D.5 Proof of Lemma 6

First, let i,j∈[m]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑚i,j\in[m] be a node in cluster c,c′∈rg​(𝒞0)𝑐superscript𝑐′rgsubscript𝒞0c,c^{\prime}\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) respectively such that 𝒞⋆​(j)superscript𝒞⋆𝑗\mathcal{C}^{\star}(j) and 𝒞⋆​(i)superscript𝒞⋆𝑖\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i) are the cluster labels of clusters c𝑐c and c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} respectively. D.7 Proof of Lemma 8

First, we use an intermediate Lemma from  Yin et al. (2018). This characterizes the behavior of T​r​i​m​m​e​d​M​e​a​nβ𝑇𝑟𝑖𝑚𝑚𝑒𝑑𝑀𝑒𝑎subscript𝑛𝛽TrimmedMean_{\beta} gradient estimator.

Let gc​(w)subscript𝑔𝑐𝑤g_{c}(w) be the output of TrMeanβsubscriptTrMean𝛽\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta} estimator for cluster c∈𝒞0𝑐subscript𝒞0c\in\mathcal{C}_{0} with size of cluster Scsubscript𝑆𝑐S_{c}. If Assumptions 3 holds, then

Proof.

The proof of this Lemma follows from coordinate-wise sub-exponential distribution of ∇Fc∇subscript𝐹𝑐\nabla F_{c}. Since loss per sample f​(w,z)𝑓𝑤𝑧f(w,z) is Lipschitz in each of its coordinates with Lipschitz constant Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k} for k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d]. Thus, Fc​(w)subscript𝐹𝑐𝑤F_{c}(w) is also Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k}-Lipschitz for each coordinate k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d] from Corrolary 1. Now, every subgaussian variable with variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is σ𝜎\sigma-sub exponential. Thus, each coordinate of ∇wf​(w,z)subscript∇𝑤𝑓𝑤𝑧\nabla_{w}f(w,z) is L^^𝐿\hat{L}-sub-exponential, since L^>Lk,∀k∈[d]formulae-sequence^𝐿subscript𝐿𝑘for-all𝑘delimited-[]𝑑\hat{L}>L_{k},\forall k\in[d]. The remainder of proof can be found in  (Yin et al., 2018, Appendix E.1). ∎

D.8 Proof of Lemma 3

We present the proof for this lemma here as it is a corollary of Lemma 8.

We utilize the intermediate Lemma 10. Now, if we set α=β=0𝛼𝛽0\alpha=\beta=0 and Sc=1subscript𝑆𝑐1S_{c}=1, we obtain the generalization guarantee for GD on a single node i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m]. Further, we do not need the terms of s𝑠s as they appear with β𝛽\beta, and thus, we can choose s𝑠s very large, so that we can ignore its contribution to error probability. The remainder of the proof follows that of Lemma 8.

Appendix F Additional Technical Lemmas

Lemma 11.

If f,g:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} are two μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex functions on a domain 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. Then, f+g2𝑓𝑔2\frac{f+g}{2} is also μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex on the same domain.

Proof.

If f𝑓f and g𝑔g are μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex on a domain 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}, then for any w1,w0∈𝒲subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝒲w_{1},w_{0}\in\mathcal{W}

f​(w1)𝑓subscript𝑤1\displaystyle f(w_{1}) ≥f​(w0)+⟨∇f​(w0),w1−w0⟩+μ2​∥w1−w0∥2absent𝑓subscript𝑤0∇𝑓subscript𝑤0subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\geq f(w_{0})+\left\langle\nabla f(w_{0}),w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert^{2}
g​(w1)𝑔subscript𝑤1\displaystyle g(w_{1}) ≥g​(w0)+⟨∇g​(w0),w1−w0⟩+μ2​∥w1−w0∥2absent𝑔subscript𝑤0∇𝑔subscript𝑤0subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\geq g(w_{0})+\left\langle\nabla g(w_{0}),w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert^{2}

Adding the above equations, we get

f​(w1)+g​(w1)2≥f​(w0)+g​(w0)2+⟨∇f​(w0)+∇g​(w0)2,w1−w0⟩+μ2​∥w1−w0∥2𝑓subscript𝑤1𝑔subscript𝑤12𝑓subscript𝑤0𝑔subscript𝑤02∇𝑓subscript𝑤0∇𝑔subscript𝑤02subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝜇2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\frac{f(w_{1})+g(w_{1})}{2}\geq\frac{f(w_{0})+g(w_{0})}{2}+\left\langle\frac{\nabla f(w_{0})+\nabla g(w_{0})}{2},w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rangle+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert^{2}

Thus, f+g2𝑓𝑔2\frac{f+g}{2} is also μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex. ∎

Lemma 12.

If f,g:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} are two L𝐿L-smooth functions on a domain 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. Then, f+g2𝑓𝑔2\frac{f+g}{2} is also L𝐿L-smooth on the same domain.

Corollary 1.

If f,g:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} are two L𝐿L-Lipschitz functions on a domain 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W}. Then, f+g2𝑓𝑔2\frac{f+g}{2} is also L𝐿L-Lipschitz on the same domain.

Proof.

Consider the following term for any w1,w0∈𝒲subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝒲w_{1},w_{0}\in\mathcal{W}

∥∇f​(w1)+∇g​(w1)2−∇f​(w0)+∇g​(w0)2∥delimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝑤1∇𝑔subscript𝑤12∇𝑓subscript𝑤0∇𝑔subscript𝑤02\displaystyle\left\lVert\frac{\nabla f(w_{1})+\nabla g(w_{1})}{2}-\frac{\nabla f(w_{0})+\nabla g(w_{0})}{2}\right\rVert ≤12​∥(∇f​(w1)−∇f​(w0))+(∇g​(w1)−∇g​(w0))∥absent12delimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝑤1∇𝑓subscript𝑤0∇𝑔subscript𝑤1∇𝑔subscript𝑤0\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert(\nabla f(w_{1})-\nabla f(w_{0}))+(\nabla g(w_{1})-\nabla g(w_{0}))\right\rVert
≤12​(∥∇f​(w1)−∇f​(w0)∥+∥∇g​(w1)−∇g​(w0)∥)absent12delimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝑤1∇𝑓subscript𝑤0delimited-∥∥∇𝑔subscript𝑤1∇𝑔subscript𝑤0\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2}(\left\lVert\nabla f(w_{1})-\nabla f(w_{0})\right\rVert+\left\lVert\nabla g(w_{1})-\nabla g(w_{0})\right\rVert)
≤12​(L​∥w1−w0∥+L​∥w1−w0∥)absent12𝐿delimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0𝐿delimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2}(L\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert+L\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert)
≤L​∥w1−w0∥absent𝐿delimited-∥∥subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤0\displaystyle\leq L\left\lVert w_{1}-w_{0}\right\rVert

In the second inequality, we use the triangle inequality of norms. For the third inequality, we use the L𝐿L-smoothness of f𝑓f and g𝑔g. Thus, f+g2𝑓𝑔2\frac{f+g}{2} is also L𝐿L-smooth The proof of the corollary is same as above, by replacing terms of ∇f∇𝑓\nabla f and ∇g∇𝑔\nabla g by f𝑓f and g𝑔g respectively. ∎

Lemma 13.
